text:
Before HBS, I looked at jobs
that will give me, frankly,

the most compensation,
the highest probability
of moving up.

As a first-generation
immigrant who didn't really

come from a lot, having the
practicality of moving up

in society to achieve
the American dream
was very important.

I don't think there's
anything wrong with that,

but I think because I was so
focused on being practical,

I didn't allow
myself to be happy.

And coming to Harvard
Business School

clearly gives me, it gave me
a platform to dare to dream,

to try something a
little different,
to go off the beaten path.

I think there are different
degrees of dreaming.

I came to business school
with a pregnant wife

and a two-year-old child, and
now here we are in the journey.

We have two beautiful
girls, four and one.

It's not easy, but we learned
a lot throughout the process

and trying to balance
schoolwork and finding

the right job for the
family, not just for myself.

And that was really important
for me to learn too.

Halfway through my
summer internship,

I realized this
is not a good fit.

I was away from home
four days a week.

I want to be home every
night to put my kids to bed.

I want to be a full-time parent,
in the sense that I don't want

to miss the critical
moments in their life,

and I don't want to miss
the little things either.

So immediately, I thought,
OK, I need some help.
I can't do this by myself.

Luckily, CPD was ever present
even through the summer.

So I called up my coach,
started talking to them

about what I'm struggling with
and how I should move forward,

some sort of reassurance that
I'm not making the wrong choice
by choosing not to go back.

And I think speaking to my
Career Coach early and frequent,

even during the summer
internship, was really helpful.

I am taking a role in
strategic finance at a company.

I'm excited to
try something new,

to be hands on as an operator
of a business as opposed
to an advisor.
So I want to be part of it.

I want to be able to make a
difference in what they do,

not just watching or
observing on the sidelines.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
